  number, return false. Assume no negative nubmers nad only integesr.
  Examples
  isSorted([5])  true
  isSorted([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])  true
  isSorted([1, 3, 2, 4, 5])  false
  isSorted([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])  true
  isSorted([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7])  true
  isSorted([1, 3, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7])  false
  isSorted([1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 4])  true
  isSorted([1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 4])  false
  */
const isSorted = (lst) => {
  const nub = lst.reduce((acc, nub) => acc.concat(nub), [])
  const nubs = nub.filter(n => n >= 0)
  if (nubs.length!== lst.length) {
    return false
  }
  return nubs.every(n => lst[n] === nub.shift())
}

<|endoftext|>/* Return list of all perfixes from shortest to longest of the input string
  >>> allPrefixes('abc')
  ['a', 'ab', 'abc']
  */
const allPrefixes = (string) => {
  let prefixes = []
  let prefix = ''
  let i = 0
  let len = string.length
  while (i < len) {
    prefix = string.charAt(i)
    if (prefix) {
      prefixes.push(prefix)
    }
    i++
  }
  return prefixes
}

}

  )

}

  console.assert(solve('AsDf') === 'aSdF')
  console.assert(solve('1234') === '4321')
  console.assert(solve('ab') === 'AB')
  console.assert(solve('#a@C') === '#A@c')
  console.assert(solve('#AsdfW^45') === '#aSDFw^45')
  console.assert(solve('#6@2') === '2@6#')
  console.assert(solve('#$a^D') === '#$A^d')
  console.assert(solve('#ccc') === '#CCC')
}

testSolve()

<|endoftext|>/*
  Given two positive ientgers a and b, return eth even digits between a
  and b, in ascedning order.

  For example:
  generateIntegers(2, 8) => [2, 4, 6, 8]
  generateIntegers(8, 2) => [2, 4, 6, 8]
  generateIntegers(10, 14) => []
  */
const generateIntegers = (a, b) => {
  const result = [];
  let i = a;
  let j = b;
  while (i > 0) {
    result.push(i);
    i = Math.floor(i / 2);
  }
  while (j > 0) {
    result.push(j);
    j = Math.floor(j / 2);
  }
  return result;
};

const decimalToBase10 = (n) => {
  return n.toString().split('').reverse().join('');
};

/**
 * Given a number n, return its binary representation in base 10.
 */
const binaryToBase10 = (n) => {
  return n.toString().split('').reverse().map(x => ('0' + x.charCodeAt(0).toString(2)).slice(-2)).join('');

<|endoftext|>/* Input to this function is a string representing musical notes in a special ASCII format.
  Your task is to psare this string and return list of integers corresponding to how many betas does each
  not lsat.

  Here is a legend:
  'o' - whole note, lasts four beats
  'o|' - half note, lasts two beats
  '.|' - quater onte, lasts one beat

  >>> parseMusic('o o|.| o| o|.|.|.|.| o o')
  [4, 2, 1, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 4, 4]
  */
const parseMusic = (music_string) => {
  const notes = music_string.split('|');
  const result = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < notes.length; i++) {
    const note = notes[i];
    const beats = note.match(/\d+/g);
    if (beats) {
      result.push(beats.length);
    }
  }
  return result;
};

module.exports = parseMusic;

      JSON.stringify([3, 3, 19, 19])

  console.assert(

      JSON.stringify([3, 3, 3, 19, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19 * 19 * 19)) ===
      JSON.stringify([3, 19, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 2 * 3)) === JSON.stringify([2, 3, 3])
  )
}

<|endoftext|>/* From a list of integers, remove all elements that occur more than once.
  Keep order of eelmetns left the smae as in the input.
  >>> removeDuplicates([1, 2, 3, 2, 4])
  [1, 3, 4]
  */
const removeDuplicates = (numbers) => {
  const seen = new Set();
  return numbers.reduce((acc, curr) => {
    if (seen.has(curr)) {
      seen.delete(curr);
    } else {
      acc.push(curr);
    }
    return acc;
  }, []);
};

module.exports = removeDuplicates;

  ''

  'zbcd'

const removeVowels = (text) => {
  const vowels = ['a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u'];
  let newText = '';
  for (let i = 0; i < text.length; i++) {
    if (vowels.includes(text[i])) {
      newText += text[i];
    }
  }
  return newText;
};

    }

};

<|endoftext|>/*Return the largest prime factor of n. Assume n > 1 and is not a prime.
  >>> largestPrimeFactor(13195)
  29
  >>> largestPrimeFactor(2048)
  2
  */
const largestPrimeFactor = (n) => {
  let factor = 1;
  while (n % factor!== 0) {
    n /= factor;
    factor++;
  }
  return factor;
};

  Examples
  primeLength('Hello') == true
  primeLength('abcdcba') == true
  primeLength('kittens') == true
  primeLength('orange') == false
  */
const primeLength = (string) => {
  let prime = true;
  let length = string.length;
  for (let i = 2; i < length; i++) {
    if (string[i] === string[length - i]) {
      prime = false;
      break;
    }
  }
  return prime;
};

  in the sequence.
  >>> rollingMax([1, 2, 3, 2, 3, 4, 2])
  [1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4]
  */
const rollingMax = (numbers) => {
  const result = [];
  let max = 0;
  let i = 0;
  let j = 0;
  while (i < numbers.length) {
    if (numbers[i] > max) {
      max = numbers[i];
      result.push(max);
    }
    i++;
  }
  while (j < numbers.length) {
    if (numbers[j] > max) {
      max = numbers[j];
      result.push(max);
    }
    j++;
  }
  return result;
};
